Description: Rim and body sherd of South Ionian pottery mug; very micaceous light red-brown clay; interior: reserved band at top of rim, glazed (fired red) below; exterior reserved; inscription on exterior.
Curator's comments: The modern inscription 'HERA' on the interior surface of the sherd indicates the sherd's findspot as the temenos of Hera. The rim and interior paint find parallels with Samian Hera cups. However, unlike Hera cups which have dipinto dedications to the goddess, this cup has a graffito. Other similar mugs were found in the Sanctuary of Aphrodite at Miletus and thus this shape is not exclusive to Hera or, probably, Samos. For parallels with Hera cups, see British Museum 1888,0601.401, 1888, 0601.402, 1888.0601.403, and 1888,0601.405, but especially 1888,0601.404 which is very close in fabric and profile. For parallels with another similar mug with a graffito inscription, see Cambridge Fitzwilliam GR.227.1899.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GE.899) (Phase 3)
